answers.author: Paul Leistner
answers.text:
I just read a good article that may be helpful to you:  Morse, Ricardo S. “Citizens Academies: Local Governments Building Capacity for Citizen Engagement.” Public Performance & Management Review, Vol. 36, No. 1, September 2012, pp. 79-101.
The Univ of North Carolina has a lot of good information about Citizen Academies at:  H:\Paul's ONI Files\Brian\Training\Citizen Academies\Citizen Academies UNC School of Government.mht
A couple years ago, here in Portland, Oregon, the leaders of Portland's seven neighborhood district coalitions worked with the City of Portland Office of Neighborhood Involvement and developed a plan for a citywide community leadership academy. We still hope to implement this at some point. I've attached a summary of the proposal. 
I'm happy to exchange further about citizen academies. We've been gathering information on different models for a while and are very interested in learning more.

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Hi Ray!  I have heard that you are pretty good at the design and implementation of citizen academies yourself!   In addition to the answers you receive, would you mind sharing some of your thoughts and approaches?  I believe the ICMA audience would truly benefit from learning about the adult-to-adult, community (versus purely governmental) approach, interspersed with great "Peter Block" approaches to community building, that you have advocated and practiced.  Thanks Ray!!!!

answers.author: William Lutz
answers.text:
Hi Ray.  We run a very good program here in Piqua.  In fact, our program was recently recognized by the Ohio City/County Management Association as an award winning Citizen Engagement program.  
Our program relies heaving on providing once-in-a-lifetime experiences rather than just putting out information.  Our Police Department takes our participants to a laser-gun simulator where we allow residents to fire guns (a participant favorite), our Public Works Department puts up a snow plow obstacle course and our Development Department does a grant writing exercise.  This just a taste of what we do.
We have run this program three times and have had 60 people go through the program, not bad for a community of 20,000.
